text: I hurry upstairs. The corridor is unnervingly quiet. Her door isn’t locked—as if she already knew I would come.
“…Who are you, really? And why didn’t you step in just now?”
A soft sigh comes from inside, like something heavy being forced out of her chest.
“Who I am isn’t something you need to know right now.”
“Then at least tell me this: why did you just stand there while I was getting beaten? I saw your sword—you’re a swordswoman, aren’t you? What about your responsibility?”
She falls silent for two seconds, then answers plainly: “Because I’m too tired.”
“It’s not that you weren’t worth saving. I just truly couldn’t keep going.”
The door opens slightly. She stands behind it, face pale, dark circles heavy as if she hasn’t slept for days. Yet the hand holding her sword is still steady.
“I used to step in for things like that. Many times.”
“But today, I don’t have the strength. If you want an explanation, that’s the only one: I’m so tired that even lifting my hand feels painful.”
“…So you want me to understand you?”
“Yes.” She nods. “You can blame me. Just don’t act recklessly. If you had gone head-to-head with him today, you would have died.”
“How do you know I would’ve died?”
“I’ve seen it.” She says it calmly. “That’s why I can’t be bothered pretending this is our first time meeting.”
“Listen. Don’t go outside. Tonight is dangerous.”
“You don’t have to understand the reason. You just have to do as I say.”
Her tone isn’t harsh—if anything, it’s gentle. Like someone trying to leave a way out for a person who doesn’t know the full truth.
“Go downstairs,” she adds. “Put medicine on it. Don’t push yourself.”
The door closes slowly. It doesn’t feel like rejection—more like she truly doesn’t have the strength to keep the conversation going.
I stand in the corridor, realizing for the first time: her indifference earlier might not have been apathy—she might simply have been on the verge of breaking.
